Unfortunately, he did, but that just goes to show you what holographic technology had been doing all that time.
Well, since then, 12 years have passed, and Holoconnects has taken up the torch in the world of holographics with their latest and greatest with Holobox, currently showcased at CES 2024.
Let’s take a closer look and see if we can tell immersive graphics from reality and find out what all the fuss is about.

The holographic interfaces play a pivotal role in offering a more immersive and detailed perspective on patient data, empowering medical experts to conduct thorough assessments. One of the key advantages lies in the ability for professionals to remotely collaborate, enabling experts from diverse locations to virtually engage in patient intakes and share their expertise.
The Future of Hospitality
In terms of the hospitality industry, the Holobox is emerging as an innovative solution to enhance guest experiences. It offers a new way to provide concierge services, display hotel amenities, or even to act as a virtual tour guide.

Really what the Holobox has done is more than what it’s done. It’s given us the equivalent of paper and pen with the freedom to come up with the new application for this incredible tech. You really are only limited with your own mind when it comes to this thing, so yeah, maybe we’re witnessing the new revolution similar to smartphones 15 years ago, we might have a new take on reality, and yeah, i’m ready for it.

Holograms have long been a staple of science fiction, but they are now becoming a reality thanks to Holoconnects, a leading technology provider of AI-powered holographic solutions. This company is dazzling the attendees of CES 2024 with its lifelike, highly advanced hologram technology, which can create 3D holographic visualizations of people, products, or logos.
The company's products are Holobox, the Modular Holobox, and the Holobox Mini, which can project holograms of anything you want, such as yourself, your favorite celebrity, or your brand logo. The devices are very easy to use; you need electricity and the internet to bring holograms to any location. They also have a touch system, so you can interact with and control the holograms.
The Holobox and the Holobox Mini are available in black, white, or a custom design and offer immersive and interactive experiences that deliver unparalleled engagement and impact. The Modular Holobox is designed for Google/Android and can be customized to fit any space or need, such as creating bigger holograms of cars or animals.
Holoconnects
Holoconnects' holographic technology has numerous applications across various industries, including hospitality, advertising, education, entertainment, and more.
"We thrive on pushing the boundaries of innovation, transforming the ordinary into something extraordinary," said André Smith, founder and CEO of Holoconnects. "We believe our technology will profoundly impact all industry sectors and contribute to a more sustainable, fossil-free world, as speakers can be live beamed to any Holobox location, reducing CO2 emissions caused by air travel. CES provides an excellent platform for us to connect with the world's leading innovators and showcase the limitless possibilities of holograms."
Interesting Engineering's interaction with Holoconnects at CES 2024
During our visit to CES 2024, we had the opportunity to interview Marc Hiemstra, a sales team member at Holoconnects, and ask him some questions about the company and its products. Marc told us about their three products, the Holobox, the Modular Holobox, and the Holobox Mini, which can project holograms of any image, such as people, products, or logos. He explained that their products are very easy to use and only require electricity and internet to bring holograms anywhere.
When asked about their holographic technology use cases, Marc mentioned various industries, including hospitality, advertising, education, and entertainment, where their products can be utilized. He gave examples like creating virtual hosts or receptionists in the hospitality industry and live or pre-recorded holograms of speakers, celebrities, or experts in education and entertainment.
Marc also talked about their clients and partners who are already using their technology in various ways, including UNICEF and CERF, who have partnered with Holoconnects to create holograms that raise awareness and support for their causes. D&B The Facility Group and CIC Hospitality also use their products as virtual hosts and hotel receptionists.
When asked about the difference between their technology and other avatars or virtual characters available in the market, Marc explained that their technology creates realistic and interactive holograms. Their holograms are designed to capture the appearance, voice, and gestures of the person or object being projected, and they also have a 3D effect.
Regarding competition in the holographic market, Marc confirmed that they have competitors, but he believes that Holoconnects has the best technology and price. Their products are more affordable and scalable than their competitors. They also offer customization options, such as the Modular Holobox, which can create bigger holograms of cars or animals.
Marc informed us that they have already entered the US market and have an office in Miami, which started a few months ago. They are also launching their latest Modular Holobox innovation at CES 2024. This product combines multiple Holoboxes to create bigger and better holograms.
Finally, Marc shared that the company has experienced significant growth since its inception three years ago. They have 25 employees and are growing more than 100% every year. Holoconnects has also expanded its market reach and has clients and partners all over the world. They are proud of their achievements and excited about the future.

Our team of consumer tech reporters has been in Las Vegas since the weekend, tracking all of the new products being announced at CES. Of all the gadgets, apps, and concepts on display, we have found this collection of products to be exemplary. These things are fun, they are useful, and they solve a particular problem by using technology in a new way. They may exhibit smart design or groundbreaking feats of engineering. Or the product's creator may have simply seen the future and was able to realize it in an object you can touch, hold, ride, or wear. This is the best of CES 2024.
Best Health Tech: Vivoo at Home UTI Diagnostic Test
If you’re a woman, getting a urinary tract infection is one of life’s more common and miserable afflictions. Six out of 10 adult women experience them. It burns when you pee, and the infection travels up to your kidneys, then you have to pee all the time. Health tech company Vivoo follows up on the success of last year’s smart toilet gadget with an at-home UTI diagnostic test kit. If you suspect you have a UTI, instead of scheduling a doctor’s appointment and peeing in a cup, you download the app, pee on a stick, and scan the strip with your phone. Vivoo’s deep learning image processing helps determine the results, which you can then send to your doctor to get a prescription to clear up the infection, as well as some necessary and immediate relief. The company also offers vaginal pH test strips so that you can be proactive about preventing future infections. The tests are currently awaiting FDA clearance, but later this year they will be available for next-day delivery via Amazon and other online retailers. —Adrienne So
Best Smart Home: Eureka Dual Washing Bot
No one has ever said, “I wish my washer, dryer, robot vacuum, and robot mop were all in one device.” But once you’ve seen this domestic mashup, you can never unsee it. And you will want it to be a part of your life; the combination of several large, bulky cleaning appliances in one convenient location makes a lot of sense. Eureka’s robot vacuum lives in the pedestal beneath the combo washer-dryer unit, and it comes out of hiding to clean the floors. The robovac has all the advanced AI dirt detection smarts you’d expect, but the real innovation here is purely mechanical. The robot mop’s dirty water tank drains into the same pipe as the washing machine. With one fell swoop, you solve time, energy, space, and the hassle of having to empty stinky floor-cleaning water into a sink. Right now, this bot combo is only available in China due to a licensing issue with the name by which the company wants to sell it in North America. But when it does become available in the United States, we’ll be jumping on that washing, drying, robot vacuuming and mopping train, too.—Adrienne So

Best Camera: Abode Edge Camera
Abode’s brand-new security camera caught our attention at CES for one big reason: its crazy W-Fi range. The Abode Edge Camera has a Wi-Fi HaLow system made by Morse Micro, giving it over a mile of wireless range. Your mileage may (literally) vary depending on your property’s environment, of course. But instead of attaching the security camera to the outside of your home to get it as close to the Wi-Fi router as possible, you can simply connect the base station to your Wi-Fi network, then place the camera anywhere on your property and mount it facing your home instead of away from it, giving you a better view of your whole house. A six-month battery gives you the freedom to put it whenever suits you best without worrying about a power source. The camera has object detection to distinguish things like packages, pets, and people. It also has face recognition to identify known visitors. You can program it to only alert you about certain things, or faces it doesn’t recognize. The Abode Edge will be available within the next few months for $199. Abode is also launching a single-camera subscription plan at $4 a month to access the AI features and up to 10 days of footage. —Nena Farrell
Best Transportation: Supernal S-A2
Normally we'd run a mile for saying the best transportation reveal at CES was a flying car. But here we are. Supernal's eVTOL, the S-A2, is clearly much more than a pipe dream for the company, a division of the Hyundai Motor Group. If Supernal is true to its word, you'll see this all-electric pilot-plus-four-passenger vehicle in the skies in just four years time, whisking people over distances of 25 to 40 miles at max speeds of 120 mph at up to 1,500 feet above the ground. Not only is the design striking (and honed using biomimicry based on, of all things, the shapes of bees), it's apparently going to be almost unfathomably quiet. In the vertical takeoff and landing phases, it clocks at 65 dB, which is less noisy than your dishwasher. —Jeremy White

Best Outdoors: Milo Action Communicator
If you’ve ever gone skiing or backpacking in a group, you know that the worst part of the day is when you’re supposed to meet up at the end and someone has wandered off. There you are, tired, cold, and grouchy, with no idea if your friend is just being slow, if they’ve died, or if they are simply dawdling while looking at a lizard. Milo reimagines the old familiar walkie talkie as a modern voice communication platform for small groups. Clip a palm-sized device to the outside of your jacket or backpack strap, then chat freely without worrying about clicking the right button or finding the right frequency. Milo is hands-free and phone-free, and MiloAI will talk to you when you need hands-free help fast—e.g. “Alex is in range,” or “Hey Milo, talk to Sara”. Milo can send and receive signals to other units up to 5,000 feet away in clear terrain, which is nearly a mile. The battery lasts all day on a single charge, and you can use either Bluetooth or a wired headset to listen and to chat. It’s the only thing better than having to choose between hiking or having friends. —Adrienne So
Best Weird: Looking Glass Go
Brooklyn-based Looking Glass has been creating holographic displays for years, and its latest version is a compact 6-inch digital frame called the Looking Glass Go. The screen is sharper and thinner than ever, and you can load spatial photos or 3D holograms onto it. You can even chat with 3D characters from Looking Glass’ Lifeforms app on the display. But what’s especially notable is the ability to add any 2D photo—even those from a Polaroid—and have it still deliver an incredible 3D effect on the display. This feat is possible thanks to a smart use of generative AI, which the Go uses to fill in the edges of a 2D image to give it that extra depth and make it look holographic. It’s quirky, and largely a fun little gizmo to play around with (that costs $300), but much like Google’s Project Starline, Looking Glass Go drums up a world where our screens aren’t just flat and boring. And it does this without asking you to don annoying headsets. Yay! —Julian Chokkattu

Best Parenting: Droyd Venym Electric Scooterboard
Before I had kids, I never would have guessed how many ways my own offspring would find to scoot and slide across everything. Forget bikes and scooters, they will literally slide down hills on cardboard or spin around on the floor in mixing bowls. Toy manufacturer Droyd’s electric scooterboard is quite the upgrade. It’s an electric version of a popular toy that consists of a sit-on panel with handles and spinny wheels. (I’m not proud that I know this, but I do.) Droyd’s version is intended for kids 4 and up. It looks a lot like a tarantula, all black with four spindly legs. It also comes with stickers so your kid can personalize it and make it look a tad less fearsome. Your child can control dual motors with two push-button accelerators. If it looks and seems kind of dangerous, don’t worry: it’s speed-capped at 3 mph. All it can do is make your kid a little dizzy and a lot delighted. —Adrienne So
Best Software: Apostrophy OS
There’s a new mobile operating system in town called Apostrophy OS, and it just debuted on the MC02, a $750 smartphone from the Swiss electronics company Punkt. Based on GrapheneOS, which is itself based on Android, Apostrophy replaces every element of Google’s presence from the software, giving you a a privacy-focused alternative to Android that also doesn’t sit in a completely walled garden like Apple’s iPhone. Since Apostrophy isn’t collecting or selling your data, you will need to pay a $15 monthly subscription to use the OS (it’s free for the first year), but you’re paying for the peace of mind. Every part of Apostrophy is built and operated out of Switzerland too, from the built-in VPN to the pre-installed apps like the email client and calendar. The company says Punkt is its first device partner, but it has already signed up another manufacturer, which will debut a device later this year. We’ve seen companies come and go at trying to offer a more privacy-focused version of Android, but they’ve almost all faltered when it came to apps—if you can’t use the apps available on Android and iOS, you’re doomed to obscurity. Apostrophy knows this, so it offers an app store based on the F-Droid open source app store with access to a limited number of vetted apps like Signal. There’s also a built-in wizard that helps you add the Google Play Store and Google Services Framework, enabling you to run any Android app you want. These apps are all sandboxed, meaning the underlying system access Google enjoys with Android isn't present here. (App developers will still be able to gather data about your app usage, but it’s restricted to their own apps.) The handset itself seems fairly simple, with a 6.7-inch screen, a 5,500-mAh battery, and 6 GB of RAM. There’s a 64-megapixel primary camera, but I expect the photos it captures aren’t going to wow you. The good news is we won’t have to wait long to see what the full experience is like—the MC02 ships in the next four weeks and you can order it now. —Julian Chokkattu

Best Mobile: Clicks
Miss the days of the physical keyboard on your smartphone? A handful of companies over the years have tried to bring a BlackBerry-esque smartphone experience back—even Blackberry itself. Turns out, that might not be the right approach. Enter Clicks Technology, a company formed by people that have never stopped dreaming about buttons, including YouTube gadget reviewer Michael Fisher, better known as MrMobile, and folks from fxtech, which has previously made Android phones with slide-out keyboards. Clicks is a case that adds a physical QWERTY keyboard to the iPhone. It makes for a long phone, but it’s cute and it has backlit keys! The beauty of Clicks is how the iPhone’s virtual keyboard never pops up unless you force it to, giving valuable screen real estate back to you as you type. Mac and iPad keyboard shortcuts are supported too. Typing on Clicks certainly felt fun, but the more I used it, it's the shortcuts that really started to win me over. The case is available only for the iPhone 14 Pro, iPhone 15 Pro, and iPhone 15 Pro Max, costing between $139 and $159 depending on the model, and you can order it now. Select models start shipping in February. —Julian Chokkattu
Best Home Theater: LG CineBeam Qube
One trend from CES this year has been huge TVs, so it’s refreshing to see LG come up with a solution to ever-expanding inches with a projector that is so dinky, and so nicely designed, that it could well be a character in one of the Disney animated films you can play through it. To give you a mental picture of how small the CineBeam Qube is, it measures just over 3 inches thick and 5.3 inches tall and deep. The Qube can throw out 4K images from 50 up to 120 inches, has a 450,000:1 contrast ratio, auto screen adjustment with auto-focus, and can display “digital images that enhance the ambience of the space” if you want it on when not watching it. Brightness is a little low, though, with a modest 500-lumen, so get ready to turn down the lights on movie nights. Speaking of which, yes, you can hook up the usual streaming services via LG’s webOS or use the HDMI eARC or USB C ports. Audio is built-in via a 3-watt mono speaker. But it’s all about that diminutive, attractive design, isn’t it? Oh, and see that handle? It can rotate 360 degrees so you can carry the 3.3-pound projector from room to room. Smart, small, stylish. No price yet. —Jeremy White

Best PC: Lenovo ThinkBook Plus Gen 5 Hybrid
Lenovo showed off 40 or so new products at CES 2024, but the ThinkBook Plus Gen 5 Hybrid was the coolest things we saw from the brand, and the coolest PC overall. This looks like an ordinary Windows laptop, but you can actually pull the entire display off the keyboard. When you do, that screen immediately turn into an Android 13 tablet. Meanwhile, if you connect the keyboard to an external monitor, you can continue using Windows since all of the Windows computing components are housed in the keyboard half of the assembly. There’s also a button on the keyboard to switch the operating system between Android and Windows when the screen is docked so you can use Android with a keyboard and trackpad too. We’ve seen a lot of 2-in-1 laptop designs over the years but this one is unique and streamlined. It’ll cost roughly around $2,000 and will go on sale in the second quarter of the year. —Julian Chokkattu
Best Accessory: Belkin Auto-Tracking Stand Pro with DockKit
At CES there was a near endless number of Qi2 wireless chargers, but the mobile accessory that left a lasting impression was Belkin’s Auto-Tracking Stand Pro With DockKit ($180). This MagSafe charger for the iPhone launches very soon and doubles as a 360-degree swiveling tripod for your iPhone’s camera. The hook here is that you don’t have to do anything to make sure you’re always framed properly in the shot. It’s one of the first products to support Apple’s Works With DockKit program, and this allows the Stand Pro to pair with the iPhone’s camera via NFC. After pairing, the device will swivel to always try and keep you in the frame, whether you’re using the rear or selfie camera. It also doesn’t matter which app you’re using to access the camera. You can dock the iPhone and start a presentation in Microsoft Teams or you can start filming a dance on Instagram Stories and move around the room with no worries of not being in the scene. It can be plugged into the wall or run off a battery for around five hours. We’ve seen this kind of subject-tracking tech seep into laptops, webcams, iPads, and smart displays. Soon we’ll stop asking our friends to film us and just start doing everything ourselves by using stuff like this. —Julian Chokkattu

AI Mario at CES 2024: Meet the Hologram That Nintendo Fans Can’t Stop Talking About
Table of Contents
The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2024 in Las Vegas had a surprise guest: Mario, the iconic video game character from Nintendo. But this was not the cheerful and friendly Mario that fans know and love. This was a creepy AI Mario, a hologram that spoke in a strange voice and gave bizarre answers to questions.
How AI Mario Came to Be
The AI Mario hologram was created by Proto, a company that develops hologram communications software. According to our reporter Taylor Lyles, who witnessed the spectacle on the show floor, Proto used a combination of voice recognition and AI technology to make the hologram listen and respond to attendees.
However, the result was far from convincing. The AI Mario had a noticeable off-brand Italian accent, awkward mouth movements, and stiff posture. It was clear that this was not an official Nintendo product, as the Japanese company is known to be very strict about how its characters are used and portrayed.
The Mystery of the Target Logo
The AI Mario was not the only hologram that Proto displayed at CES 2024. Other images and real people, including the CEO of AARP, were also shown on the hologram box. But what was the connection between Proto, AARP, and Mario?
Some attendees, such as @ProbChild_ and @raystrazdas, reported that they were asked by an AARP representative (not Proto) at the booth to ask Mario how to buy a game. The AI Mario replied (in his unsettling deep voice) by suggesting they look online at Target dot com. Moreover, the hologram had a small Target logo in the bottom corner, which was not present in the other demonstrations.
It seems that Proto was demonstrating its hologram AI technology for potential partnerships with retailers like Target and that it could be used as an AI assistant in stores. The AI Mario was apparently a gimmick to attract attention to the booth, but it also raised questions about the legality and ethics of using Nintendo’s intellectual property without permission.
Nintendo and AARP Disavow AI Mario
We contacted Nintendo, Proto, and Target for comments on the AI Mario situation, but only Proto responded. The company issued a statement to IGN, confirming that neither Nintendo nor AARP were involved in the “inadvertent” showing of AI Mario. The statement read:
“The AI hologram animation briefly seen today is an unfinished proof of concept tested for a client to demonstrate technological capabilities and innovation. It is not intended for commercial release. AARP and Nintendo were not involved in the inadvertent showing today. The fact that so many gamers of the world have taken notice shows that they are the best fans in the world and we salute them.”
A Poor Imitation of Nintendo’s Past Work
The AI Mario incident was not only creepy but also disappointing for Nintendo fans. It reminded them of the times when Nintendo had actually done something similar, but much better. In the past, Nintendo had used the voice of Charles Martinet, the official voice actor of Mario and Luigi, to make the characters talk in real time to people at events like New York Comic Con and Nintendo New York. The difference was that Martinet was hidden somewhere off-camera, listening and responding to questions in a natural and authentic way.
The AI Mario hologram was a poor imitation of Nintendo’s past work and a disrespectful use of its beloved character. We hope that Nintendo will take action to protect its intellectual property and that Proto will learn from its mistakes and respect the rights of other creators.
What is the history of hologram technology?
Hologram technology is the science of creating and displaying three-dimensional images using light interference patterns. The history of hologram technology can be traced back to the late 1940s, when Dennis Gabor, a Hungarian-British physicist, invented the principle of holography while trying to improve the resolution of electron microscopes. He coined the term hologram from the Greek words “holos” (whole) and “gramma” (message).
However, optical holography, which uses visible light to create holograms, did not become feasible until the invention of the laser in 1960. The laser provided a coherent and monochromatic light source that was essential for producing clear and stable holograms. The first optical hologram was made by Yuri Denisyuk, a Soviet scientist, in 1962. He used a reflection hologram technique, which allows the hologram to be viewed under white light from the same side as the light source.

First University in the UK to Install Proto for Education
The Guardian’s Rachel Hall broke the news that Loughborough University became the first school in the UK to install Proto, intending to use it for beaming in professors from its satellite campus, special speakers from MIT and around the world and to aid 3D design and medical study. “Prof Vikki Locke, the director of undergraduate studies at Loughborough business school, said students “absolutely love” the technology and have been begging for selfies with the gadget. The Original Futurist Faith Popcorn joins Proto Hologram
Axios’ Jennifer Kingon broke the news with an exclusive interview with Faith Popcorn. “I think it’s the thing before time travel,” Popcorn said. “I think we’re a bit away from time travel, but I think this is the closest we’ve gotten so far….If you’ve ever seen water in the Proto, you feel like you could drink it, the resolution is so high. It’s like the ultimate delivery system, I guess, in three-dimensional skin and bones — real life.”
CES 2024 Preview of 5 Must See “Weird Trends” includes Proto
Mashable’s always entertaining Kimberly Gedeon, included Proto among five “weird trends” coming at CES 2024. The list of only five items includes AARP’s Age Tech Collective section of the convention where Proto’s use to combat isolation is highlighted. The story also points out that Proto was recently featured on Hulu’s The Kardashians.
SoftBank deploys Proto at major Japanese basketball tournament
SoftBank Winter Cup Tournament ambassadors Yuki Kawamura, the B.League basketball star from the Yokohama B-Corsairs, and W League star Aika Hirashita of the Toyota Antelopes, will greet the fans and the artists Lil League from Exile Tribe performed the event’s official theme song – all via Proto hologram. “SoftBank Corp. is implementing this initiative to enhance visitor satisfaction by leveraging it to create new forms of communication,” the company said.
AI & Hollywood roundup includes Howie Mandel using Proto’s AI
Fox News wrote about Hollywood’s current take on the AI boom, mentioning Simon Cowell, Sheryl Crow and Justine Bateman, among those who are fearful of the tech, but also featured Howie Mandel and his investment in Proto and use of its devices and AI products in his own studio.
Tennis star Cici Bellis invests in hologram maker Proto
Sports Business Journal lead tech reporter Rob Schaefer wrote about Cici Belli’s Cartan Capital joining Proto’s current found. “[The investment] reassures us that we are on the right track, because [Bellis has] incredible vision,” Proto founder and CEO David Nussbaum told SBJ. “If we’re her first investment, that speaks volumes to me. It re-energizes me, it motivates me, to have somebody place that amount of trust and faith in Proto. We really want to invest back into the world of professional sports and entertainment as a means of education and communication and connecting people.”
Sports & health tech fund Cartan Capital invests in Proto
Sportico finance lead Brendan Coffey broke the news that retired tennis star Cici Bellis has joined Proto’s recent funding round, as the first investment from her venture fund Cartan Capital. “Our focus is on sports tech and health tech and Proto hits both of those verticals,” Bellis told Sportico. “They’ve had a lot of exposure in sports, sports stadiums, big name professional athletes… we really like the in-stadium and fan engagement angle that Proto brings.”
Fortune AI Summit Features AARP and Proto Tech for Seniors
At Fortune’s first AI summit, in San Francisco, Proto head of innovation Raffi Kryszek spoke about ProtoBot’s use for senior citizens along side AARP CIO Najeeb Uddin, Renate Nyborg,  CEO of Meeno and Ann Garnier, CEO of Lisa Health. “The biggest bottleneck for adoption of tools is friction of usability, and that’s often very prevalent in the older demographics,” said Kryszek. “There’s nothing more natural than conversation.”
Toronto Hotel Launches Virtual Concierge via Proto
The Hotel X in Toronto has launched the first virtual hologram concierge in its lobby, using Proto hologram in partnership with Canadian firm HoloMedia. Matt Black, the Hotel Director said, “A few children have asked us where she sleeps at night as the technology really makes it seem like she is in the box!”
TV Industry Building Proto Hologram into Show Content
The UK’s top AV industry magazine wrote about Hulu’s The Kardashians and Jimmy Kimmel Live both using Proto as an integrated part of their content in the same week — extending the use of the hologram technology from marketing uses (by Netflix, HBO, FITE and others) into being part of the stories. The piece also notes the use of Proto in the massive Indian hit on StarMaa/Disney+ Bigg Boss Telegu (their version of Big Brother) and on the hit Indonesian singing competition show Trending Star.
Amazon’s AWS Builder Studio features Proto for enterprise
The Wall Street Jounral’s Isabelle Bousquette wrote about the new Builder Studio from Amazon’s AWS in the historic Lord & Taylor building in Manhattan, where Proto technology is demonstrated for enterprise clients. She interviewed Raffi Kryszek, Proto’s head of AI & innovation who said,  “We have YouTube videos all over the place of people experiencing our products. It’s just not the same as having a volumetric spatial computing experience in person’…. Kryszek said Proto is currently in conversations with a large fashion brand that got interested in the tech while walking through the Builder Studio.”
The Kardashians makes Proto technology a major plot point
The Daily Mail told their 80 million global readers about Hulu’s The Kardashians’  Kris Jenner visiting Proto studios at Paris Hilton’s suggestion, learning about Proto from Howie Mandel and CEO David Nussbaum, and using it to beam to Khloe Kardashian’s house and appearing in Proto Epics and Proto Ms for a hologram heart-to-heart. It was Proto’s first time on an unscripted, non-competition show. “Now I can be in 2, 3, 4 places at once! ” said Kris Jenner.
Proto & Coca Cola present Jonas Brothers hologram at the Sphere
The Las Vegas Review Journal’s John Katsilometes broke the news that the Jonas Brothers appeared in hologram form for the first time in a Proto Epic unit at a Coca Cola event for its new AI-driven flavor, Y3000, that took place at the Sphere in Las Vegas.
People reveals Sexiest Man on Jimmy Kimmel Live using Proto
On Jimmy Kimmel Live, Patrick Dempsey was revealed to be 2023’s “Sexiest Man Alive” via an audience guessing game. The actor beamed onto the stage in a Proto Epic unit with his face covered by virtual masks. “Thanks to our friends at Proto,” said Kimmel.
Proto’s sophisticated technology helps Christie’s reach buyers
Carol Vogel of the New York Times included Proto in her look at the changes the auction industry is making, writing, Christie’s, “sophisticated technology [that] has given buyers confidence to acquire works without viewing them in person,” like the Degas that Proto beamed to San Francisco and Hong Kong which went on to sell for $41.6M.
A Paris, « Le Nez » de Giacometti en hologramme

P.K.’s Place visits Proto, talks Holograms & Hockey with Howie
Former NHL star and current ESPN host PK Subban got Proto pranked upon arriving at our Van Nuys headquarters with Howie Mandel beaming in to welcome him. PK got the chance to become an instant hologram himself before the two settled down to talk hockey.
Proto’s Holo-Fashion Avatars – from H&M, Nike – Inspire Industry
Vogue Business’ Maghan McDowell wrote about the use of avatars in fashion and beauty pointing out Proto’s use of hologram models by H&M and the RTFTK x Nike event in Tokyo featuring mo-cap suit operated holograms of digital humans designed by artist Takashi Murakami. Proto events, including early hologram “pranks” by Ellen DeGeneres and Jimmy Kimmel using Proto, have now inspired Sephora’s Nars brand with their most recent event featuring virtual ambassadors.
Proto’s First Comedy Club Home: Jimmy Kimmel’s Vegas Spot
Howie Mandel and Proto CEO David Nussbaum beamed in live from Los Angeles to Las Vegas to talk with FOX 5 More Las Vegas’ Dani Masten about the first Proto to be permanently installed on The Strip, and the first ever to be placed in a comedy club. The multiple morning segments involved Howie and David explaining how comics can beam in to do shows live from anywhere in the world and also showed hologram Jimmy Kimmel and Guillermo talking to fans. As Dani said, “It just doesn’t get cooler than this!”
Jimmy Kimmel’s Comedy Club installs first Proto in Vegas
John Katsilometes, Las Vegas’ leading entertainment journalist, broke the news in the Las Vegas Review-Journal that Jimmy Kimmel’s Comedy Club has installed a Proto Epic unit — the first permanent installation in a comedy club and the first permanent installation in Las Vegas. Jimmy Kimmel and sidekick Guillermo appear to talk to guests in hologram form and comics can beam in for live, fully interactive shows. Howie Mandel beamed in to talk to Katsilometes and said, “This technology is, I think, as exciting as the iPhone was when it came out.”
Hologram Comedy set by Andy Kindler is Hall of Fame Worthy
Erik Barnes of Cracked singled out Andy Kindler beaming from L.A. to Montreal to do his live “State of the Industry” comedy set at the Just for Laughs festival as the number one “Hall of Fame” moment for the comedian, calling it “historic.”
First Mobile Hologram Truck Launched by Proto
Featuring Proto Epic units and innovative vibration control, a truck built by Proto Korea and Creative Mut for Korean OTT giant Wavve was seen all over the Busan International Film Festival promoting the new series “Deal.”  The stars of the film appeared in hologram form and the units were linked to show room-sized versions of scenes from the film. After debuting at Busan, the hologram truck is back in Seoul, roaming the streets of Gangnam day and night.
Proto Holograms Featured All Over Busan Film Fest
Proto was everywhere at the Busan International Film Festival in October 2023. Wavve’s new mini-series “Deal” was promoted everywhere via the first mobile hologram truck, created by Proto Korea and Creative Mut. Spot TV News praised the innovative marketing concept and its witty connection to the narrative of the TV show being promoted.
Proto’s First Use in Museum Exhibition Debuts in Paris
The museum in Paris has utilized Proto technology to display a rare sculpture by Alberto Giacometti that was too delicate to be transported from its home in Switzerland. The life-like presentation, using a Proto M, produced by the museum and Proto allows viewers to see the early version of The Nose, alongside all of the other versions of the piece including the one recently purchased by Justin Sun.
The Stadium Business on Proto at Kansas City’s Royals Stadium
The top news outlet for the sports arena and stadium business wrote about the debut of the George Brett hologram produced for the Kansas City Royals by their agency Pine Tar Collective and Transcend Holographic Media. Hall of Famer Brett told the story for the famous Pine Tar Bat incident via hologram, up close and personal with fans during a three day Royals vs. Yankees series.
Fondation Giacometti Unveils Hologram of “The Nose” in Paris
Proto hologram is part of a museum exhibition for the first time, and making its first public appearance in France, at the Fondation Giacometti. Using a Proto M to display a version of Alberto Giacometti’s sculpture The Nose that was too fragile to ship from it’s home in Switzerland, the Fondation has found a perfect use case for holograms and the art world.
Korea’s Giant CGV Theater Chain Deploys Proto
My Daily Korea reporter Kwak Myeong-dong wrote about Proto’s two major activations at the Busan International Film Festival including top theater chain CGV’s “Hi BIFF, High CGV” event which turns visitors into instant holograms via the Proto Epic with magazine cover-style overlays.  The ‘Narcissistic Photo Zone’ is part of CJOliveNetworks. Around town Proto could also be seen on the mobile hologram truck created for TV platform Waave. Both activations were created by Proto Korea and Creative Mut.
Kansas City Royals Debut George Brett Hologram at Stadium
Sports Business Journal’s Joe Lemire broke the news that Transcend Holographic Media, in partnership with the Kansas City Royals, produced a hologram of Hall of Fame player George Brett telling the story of the famous Pine Tar Bat Incident. The hologram was presented in a Proto Epic unit at Kauffman Stadium during a series of games between the Royals and the Yankees.  Tony Snethen, the Kansas City Royals Vice President of Brand Innovation and agency lead of Pine Tar Collective, said “Working with Transcend Holographic Media and Proto provides valuable new tools for engaging and providing a stadium experience that’s second to none.”
George Brett Hologram Tells Infamous Pine Tar Bat Story
Kansas City’s local news leader KCWE visited Kauffman Stadium to meet the George Brett hologram and hear the legend of the Pine Tar Bat incident. The hologram was produced by the Kansas City Royals in association with Transcend Holographic Media. “I remember watching the pine tar game as a child who was one of the biggest Royals fans in the world. How Chatbots with voices – like ProtoBot – will change everything
Sascha Brodsky of Lifewire spoke with Proto AI lead Raffi Kryszek about how talking AI bots — like ProtoBot, the first AI hologram avatar, will change the world. “Interacting with AI chatbots using spoken words fosters a sense of natural communication, catering to our innate human preference for verbal exchange,” Proto Inc.’s AI lead, Raffi Kryszek, told Lifewire via email. “This mode of interaction is not only often faster than typing but also heightens convenience, especially on devices or in settings where typing isn’t feasible.”
Proto’s Conversational AI holograms for business
UK tech for enterprise site Tech HQ’s Fiona Jackson wrote about her demo trying ProtoBot, the first AI hologram chat assistant, and an in depth conversation about ProtoGPT with CEO David Nussbaum and AI lead Raffi Kryszek.
Verizon features Proto at
London 5G Innovation Hub
Corriere della Sera wrote about Verizon’s new 5G hub in London, which features Proto hologram. Reporter Chiara Barison also discussed Verizon’s collaboration with Burberry to use Proto.
Proto Hologram makes Indian TV debut
For its seventh season premiere on September 3rd, Bigg Boss Telugu debuted Los Angeles-startup Proto hologram’s technology for the first time on Indian television with host Nagarjuna beaming in to a Proto Epic hologram unit to talk to a contestant, actress Priyanka Jain (Mouna Ragam, Janaki Kalaganalede). Bigg Boss is India’s version of Big Brother.
Bigg Boss Telugu, originally produced by Endemol Shine India which is now merged with Banjiay, and airing on Star Maa and Disney+ Hotstar, is shot at Annapurna Studios, Hyderabad
Dallas Cowboys Owner Jerry Jones AI Hologram at AT&T Stadium
Sports Illustrated wrote about Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones installing a Proto Epic at AT&T Stadium as part of the special “Owners Tour” behind the scenes. The experience allows fans to ask Jerry Jones questions and, using AI technology, his hologram is able to respond instantly. The debut of the Jerry Jones hologram in the Proto unit was covered by hundreds of news outlets all over the world.
In the “Zoom of the Future” we talk with holograms
Switzerland’s top paper sent their Silicon Valley correspondent, Marie-Astrid Langer,  to visit Proto’s Los Angeles headquarters — and to witness Jimmy Kimmel becoming a hologram in person.
William Shatner interroge l’IA sur l’amour, la peur, et c’est très philosophique
France’s top tech news site reports on video of Proto advisor William Shatner talking through his fears of AI with ProtoBot, finding the exchange fascinating and deep. Reporter Maxence Glineur  calls ProtoBot is much more sophisticated than Alexa or Siri and writes, “Shatner raises questions that many SF thinkers and writers have been asking for decades, if not no longer. It is therefore not difficult to see him again here in the shoes of a Captain Kirk in the middle of one of his fascinating missions.”
William Shatner introduces ProtoBot to the World
To introduce Proto’s hologram AI chatbot — the world’s first — Reuters visited William Shatner at his office in Los Angeles and witness his discussion with ProtoBot about AI ethics and emotions.  Reuters’ Rollo Ross broke the news that ProtoBot will launch September 8th and be included in every Proto unit sold. “I’m asking ProtoBot questions that ordinarily a computer doesn’t answer,” Shatner told Reuters. “A computer answers two plus two, but does ProtoBot know what love is? Can ProtoBot understand sentience? Can they understand emotion? Can they understand fear?”
Voice of America Arabic’s Proto Hologram Documentary
Airing across the Arab-speaking world, Voice of America produced a documentary about Proto hologram with a visit to the Los Angeles studio to try holoportation and meet the brilliant Protopians that make it a reality. Interviewees include David Nussbaum, Noah Rothstein, Tristan Savage Tate, Jocelyn Harper, Molly Lavik, Joe Wallace, Nick Kury, Raffi Kyrszek and Howie Mandel.
VC Spotlight: Christie’s, Proto & the Future of Art
At Christie’s Art + Tech conference, Bloomberg’s VC Spotlight spoke with Christie’s Devang Thakkar about Christie’s Venture investment arm and its investment in emerging technologies including Proto. At the conference at Rockefeller Center event, both the Proto Epic and the Proto M were in action.
MTN Nigeria beams top artists on Proto hologram tour
The Nigerian tech leader MTN, used the Proto Epic to tour with the nation’s top Hip Hop artists including Qdot and Slowdog, marking the first time the full size proto unit and holographic platform has been used on the continent. Fans were able to interact with the stars at a series of pop up events across the country.
Tottenham Hotspurs Star Opens Tumi’s Proto Pop Up in Seoul
Dazed and Confused Korea featured Son Heung-Min, the Premier League star player from the Tottenham Hotspurs as he opened Tumi’s new Essentially Beautiful pop up store in Seoul. The Proto Epic at the center of the experience displayed Tumi luggage in hologram form and allowed visitors to become instant holograms themselves, with anime filters.
GovTech features Proto in its Emerging Tech news roundup
The authority on IT for state and local governments included Proto’s work with Gallaudet University, exploring how hologram communications can improve remote ASL learning, in its Emerging Tech news round up: “At the Visual-Centric Teaching and Learning Symposium hosted by Gallaudet this spring, university president Roberta J. Cordano “beamed” into the Epic to interact with attendees using American Sign Language. The school is interested in the technology’s potential to host guest speakers from around the world.”
Comedian Tom Segura on Proto: “It was like I was in the room.”
HITC’s Filiz Mustafa wrote about Tom Segura beaming into Whitney Cummings’ Roast of Bert Kriescher’s Roast on Only Fans TV, calling the experience “Terrifying” because it was so much more real than he expected. Segura beamed from Austin, Texas to the roast in Los Angeles, surprising his buddy Bert by showing up as a hologram in a Porta-Potty, specially constructed around the Proto Epic unit for the gag.
NHL’s Ducks make news with Proto hologram jersey reveal
NBC 4 Los Angeles covered the Anaheim Ducks’ NHL Draft party where their pick Leo Carlsson beamed live from Nashville to the Honda Center to reveal the new 30th anniversary jersey to fans and media for the first time. Leo could see, hear and interact with the fans of his new home team in real time.

In the feature, “Tom Segura Answeres the Web’s Most Asksed Questions,” the comedian talks about how he beamed in via Proto from Austin to the Bert Kriescher’s roast put on by Whitney Cummings which tried on Only Fans TV”  “I was absolutely mesmerized by this. Whitney Cummings is great comic and a producer and she put together a roast of my buddy Bert Kreischer and I couldn’t make it and she was like, Oh, I’ll just send a crew to your studio and you can do your set on this latest and greatest hologram. I thought it was going to look like, oh, like sort of a rough image, like what you imagine a hologram was kind of from 20 years ago. Dude, it looks like I am standing in the room. It is actually terrifying.”

First European university to host lectures by Proto hologram
By AV Magazine
in Displays, Education, UK&I January 24, 2024 0
Loughborough University will beam in lecturers from other institutions and from a satellite campus, will show 3D objects, and provide information via an avatar.
Loughborough University is set to become the first higher education institution in Europe to host guest lecturers in a Proto holographic display booth.
The technology will be formally introduced into the curriculum in 2025 after a year of experimentation, according to the Guardian website.
The university plans to bring in sports scientists from MIT, teach fashion students how to create immersive shows and test management students on how to navigate tricky situations, using the technology. It will also be able to beam in colleagues from the university’s London campus.
Proto’s holographic display will be used to present 3D objects for closer inspection where they can be rotated and studied in detail. Students will also be able to showcase their own outputs to broader audiences with the display.
Pre-recorded messages and talks from industry partners and alumni are on the agenda, too, together with interactive guidance and information for prospective students, parents and guardians, provided by an AI avatar.
Speaking to the Guardian, Prof Vikki Locke, director of undergraduate studies at Loughborough business school, said students “absolutely love” the technology and have been begging for selfies with the gadget. They would prefer “a guest speaker from industry beaming into a classroom to a 2D person on the wall”, she added.
Zoom calls led students to “feel like they were watching TV … there’s a distance. A holographic image is a lot more engaging and real to them.”
“Education has always been a key use case as we developed the Proto platform,” said David Nussbaum, inventor and CEO of Proto Inc. “In Loughborough we have a perfect partner to show all the ways the technology can boost education, in an environmentally sound way, for the first time in England.”
Proto holographic display booths were adopted by the University of Central Florida in 2021 to support medical education, supported by a $75,0000 grant from a US health services provider.
The company has also recently unveiled a platform aimed at the retail industry, combining its holographic display with conversational AI capabilities.
